entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: Writing Between Silence and Experience
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

My name is Hakan. I‚Äôm a husband and a father, and my two girls are my greatest inspiration in life. I work as an Expert in SAP HANA Solution Support, and today I‚Äôd like to share a bit about my hobby as part of the SAP Community Hobbies series. Alongside the technical world, one constant has stayed with me since my youth: writing. Writing is not a project for me, but a state of mind. It‚Äôs the moment when experiences, thoughts, and encounters begin to take shape, whether they come from everyday life or from situations far outside the comfort zone.
 

Taking a moment to enjoy the view over Lake L√ºnersee after a long glacier climb.

Over the years, writing has become the place where movement turns into reflection, intensity into clarity, and silence into meaning.
 
 
A quiet moment in the Mongolian landscape, letting distance and silence speak.
 

How and when did you start this hobby? What sparked your interest?
I started writing very early, long before my notes turned into books. Even as a teenager, I wanted to capture what life does to me, traveling, people, nature, silence, and also the intense or challenging moments. I lived a fast and intense life: mountains, horses, archery, film and stunt projects, traveling through remote regions, motorcycling, martial arts, and even periods where I spent time forging metal and making knives. 


Forging metal taught me focus, patience, and respect for the process.



These were moments that demanded absolute focus. For a period of time, I even lived as a monk, an experience that taught me the value of silence and observation. All of this leaves traces. Writing became the place where I could sort those impressions and give them meaning.
 
 
What do you love most about your hobby?
Writing connects the outer world with the inner one. It is also a form of relaxation for me, a mental reset. When I stand on a mountain or ride my motorcycle, that‚Äôs when the clearest thoughts come. In challenging situations, my mind switches into deep concentration, and those moments often become the source of later inspiration. Writing shows me what a moment truly meant and preserves something that would otherwise fade.
 

In the Alps, moving through terrain that demands focus and trust.
 
 
What challenges have you faced, and how did you overcome them?
The biggest challenge is honesty, not toward others, but toward yourself. Writing confronts you with topics you may not immediately have words for. And then there is perfectionism: the belief that something must be ‚Äúperfect‚Äù before you share it. I learned that authenticity matters more than perfection. Sometimes an unfinished thought touches more deeply than a polished one.
 
 
What has been your proudest moment or most meaningful experience?
Several readers told me that my writing expressed feelings they had carried for years but couldn‚Äôt articulate. Some said they had to pause because the words were emotionally overwhelming. Knowing that something I first wrote only for myself could give someone else comfort or clarity is incredibly meaningful to me.
 

Balance, patience, elevation.
 
 
What tools or resources would you recommend to beginners?
A pen. A digital document. A quiet moment. You don‚Äôt need more than that. Technology plays only a small role. What matters is interest, openness, and the willingness to reflect. In both writing and coaching, the approach is less about technique and more about mindset.
 
 
What tips would you give someone who wants to start?
Don‚Äôt wait until you feel ready. Perfection is the biggest enemy of beginning. Write for yourself, not for others. Curiosity is the driving force behind everything, writing, learning, and being human. And remember: your experiences are your greatest raw material. Take them seriously.
 
 
This is where thoughts settle, after the climb.
 
 
How do you continue learning and developing in your hobby?
I learn by experiencing. I travel, observe, listen, try new things, and actively seek new impressions. Whether in workshops, in nature, in conversations, or on the road, every moment contains the potential to learn something. Writing helps me make sense of those experiences. Coaching complements this because it teaches me to listen more deeply, to perceive more subtly, and to shift perspectives. Together, these practices give me a level of clarity I didn‚Äôt have before.
 
 
Are there any misconceptions about your hobby that you‚Äôd like to correct?
Many people think writing is a special talent. For me, it is more about attention and courage. And coaching is often mistaken for consulting. Coaching is not about giving answers, it‚Äôs about accompanying people so they can find their own. Both require presence, not perfection.
 
 
Where can people learn more about this hobby?
Books, podcasts, and communities are great places to start, but the best learning happens when you begin writing yourself. Five minutes a day can open a door.
 

A moment of trust.
 
 
How do you see the connection between your hobby and the SAP world?
In my work in Support, two things are constant: complexity and humanity. Writing and coaching help me connect both.
Writing sharpens clarity and expression. Coaching sharpens perception and understanding. Together, they improve how I communicate with customers and colleagues, how I assess situations, and how I share knowledge, whether in KBAs, conversations, or team coaching sessions. At the end of the day, behind every technical challenge stands a person with a concern. And that‚Äôs exactly where my two worlds meet.
 
Coming up next 
I‚Äôm happy to pass the baton to @Sumaiya, the next member of our SAP Community, who will share her hobby of home gardening and what inspires her beyond work.

Looking forward to discovering many more stories in this series.

Best regards,
Hakan

entry.title: Do you know how to Implement Manufacturing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition?
entry.content:
I recommend to access our Implementing Manufacturing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition learning journey.

Learning outcome
After completing this learning journey, you will be able to:

  • Analyze master data for discrete and process manufacturing
  • Maintain master data for manufacturing processes
  • Understand the basics and detailed steps of supply chain planning
  • Execute material requirements planning and capacity evaluation
  • Implement make-to-order and make-to-stock planning strategies
  • Use advanced planning methods in SAP S/4HANA such as pMRP, MRP Live, DDMRP and PP/DS
  • Use detailed scheduling and optimization in advanced planning
  • Describe the lifecycle of a production and process order

 

Goals
  • Get started with SAP: Building the basics
  • Develop your expertise: Skill deepening learning
  • Excel in your expertise: Advanced specialization learning
 
Please post you question related to the digital learning Journey in the Q&A area. 

Our SAP Learning Experts will get back to you as soon as possible! 
We are here to support you.


I appreciate your feedback and we will make sure to continue sharing interesting topics.

Kind regards, Lian

entry.title: Styling your Custom Frontend like SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
üé® Want to create a custom frontend that perfectly mirrors SAP Sales and Service Cloud Version 2?

When building side-by-side extensions embedded via Mashups, users expect a seamless experience ‚Äì one that feels native to the standard UI, not like a foreign add-on.

‚ú®I've created a sample application that makes this effortless! It includes ready-to-use CSS styles and design patterns that help you craft custom frontends that look and feel indistinguishable from the standard SSv2 interface.

üöÄ The result? Your extensions blend perfectly into the user's workflow, maintaining consistency, usability, and that familiar SAP experience users trust.

tl;dr:  --> Styling your Custom Frontend (Video | Github | Styleguide (html + css on git))

Before diving into my sample and my custom css let's talk about existing UI frameworks. You can get already very close by using the official libraries from SAP and there are several official options:

  • Using the official UI5 Framework
  • Using the UI5 web components for Angular, Vue, React and Svelte
  • Using the Fundamentals Library (Agnostic Styles or Libraries for Angular)

All those three have a lot of added values and are highly recommended. Recently I discussed often that especially for small extensions the UI5 Framework is to heavy and it is better to go for a more native approach. This would lead to the UI5 web components if you want to have it very standardized and to the Fundamentals library if you want it more custom / native. For my sample here I personally chose as underlying framework Vue over Angular because it is more lightweight and for my single page application with a monorepo it just seemed more suitable than a full blown Angular application. So the above options are very good options to have a maintained UI foundation for your custom frontend.

But as we know in some nuances the UX of SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2 follows a more fresh and modern look and some web components used in our Cloud Native application are just unique. And if you really want to do a fully custom app, it might be useful to only style your application with CSS but build it as you want. Exactly for this use case I put some CSS examples together.

I think a very important note here is: these examples are not maintained, published once and I cannot promise to update those but I think they still help the extension community out there to get some inspiration for their own projects.

As pictures (and source code) tell more than a thousand words you can find below the link to the video where I showcase the UI that I have build, the documentation of the CSS and the Github repo where you can find all the code:

  • Styling your Custom Frontend (Video | Github | Styleguide (html + css on git))

Now I want to give you a few examples and also explain further down a bit how I developed my custom frontend that I share.

In my use case I wanted to build a UI on top of an existing standard API from SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2 in order to purely focus in this example on a custom frontend. I chose to develop a new list view for the "Accounts" which can be embedded as a full screen mashup in the main navigation. It is not a great idea to try to re-develop a standard screen but it is a great example for showing what you can do with a custom frontend and how similar it looks and behaves. But also here, please be aware, I did not considered things like read restrictions based on org, role or territory and exactly those are the things why "re-developing" a standard list view like I did is in many cases not a good idea. I still believe it is a great example for showing the styling and building of a custom frontend.

I did build my frontend with Vue and created a very small backend with Express Node.js so that I have both as a monorepo together. I also published seperatly a styleguide so that you can use the CSS framework agnostic. 

But now let's take a look at a few screens from the application. If you want to see it in action, just take a look at the video linked above or checkout directly the source code at Github. In the video I also explain a bit more about the styling and my CSS style guide coming with the Github repository. And if you are interested in more extensibility content, you should check out my Anchor Post for my Extensibility Tutorials.

Custom Account View embedded as a full screen mashup in the standard navigation:

 Custom Account View with various elements in V2 style:

 Table Charts using the same styling and library like V2 (highcharts):

 Open Detail View, In-Iine editing and search:

 Standard quick view opens when clicking on any of the linked standard objects using custom events:

More navigation links using custom events to the standard application and form fields with V2 look:

Standard quick create of a case opening as overlay with initial parameters handed over:

Here a quick preview of the non-offical CSS styleguide shared as a simple HTML+css which you can download and launch locally:

 

I hope you enjoyed this blog article and that this helps you to build the perfect custom frontend for your individual needs!

As said initially, this is just some help from a developer for developers, I cannot provide official maintenance of those CSS styles but it may help you to build your own library that looks as close as possible like SAP Sales and Service Cloud Version 2.

Have a great day!

Jens

entry.title: Calling fresh graduates in Botswana: SAP career opportunity is now open!
entry.content:
Here‚Äôs your chance to start your career in tech consulting

If you‚Äôre a fresh graduate in Botswana, with a passion for business, technology, or data, and you want to break into the consulting world, don‚Äôt miss this SAP Young Professionals edition.

What exactly is the SAP Young Professionals program?

This is a free, full-time initiative from the Digital Skills Center that trains underemployed/ unemployed fresh graduates on SAP technologies and essential consulting skills.

By the end of the program, you‚Äôll be certified as an SAP Associate and ready to start a career within SAP customers, partners, or even within SAP itself.

Here‚Äôs What You‚Äôll Gain:

  • SAP Certification: get officially certified in SAP End-to-End Business Processes, learning how to connect departments like finance, HR, sales, and supply chain using SAP S/4HANA  
  • Consulting skills: understand how real businesses use SAP to solve problems, improve operations, and drive innovation.
  • Soft Skills: build professional confidence with training in communication, teamwork, and job interviews.

Who Can Apply?

You‚Äôre eligible if:

  • You‚Äôre legally allowed to work in Botswana.
  • You‚Äôre currently unemployed or in a non-permanent job unrelated to your career goals.
  • You have a Bachelor‚Äôs degree in Business, IT, MIS, Engineering, Data Science, or similar.
  • You graduated within the last 3 years (preferably with a strong GPA).

entry.title: Re: Requirement for Customer-Specific Transit Time in SAP
entry.content:
Transit times are usually defined at transportation zone / shipping condition / route level. If all customers in a country share the same transit time, you can maintain it at the country or zone level. But when one customer requires a different transit time, you need a way to override the default.

Here are the standard approaches available:

Route Determination with Customer-Specific Routes
SAP allows you to define routes based on shipping conditions, transportation zones, and sometimes customer master data. You can create a special route for the specific customer with a transit time of 56 days, while the default route remains 35 days for others. Transit time is then maintained in the route master.

Customer Master ‚Äì Transportation Zone Override
In the customer master (BP ‚Üí Sales Area ‚Üí Shipping tab), you can assign a different transportation zone for that customer. This zone can have its own transit time (56 days), separate from the country-level zone (35 days).

Shipping Condition Differentiation
Define a unique shipping condition for the special customer. Combine it with route determination to assign a longer transit time.

Condition-Based Transit Time (Advanced ATP / Transportation Management)
If you are using SAP TM or advanced ATP, you can model transit times more flexibly with condition records. This allows customer-specific transit times without changing master data structures.

entry.title: Issue with shipping point during Return To Vendor
entry.content:
We have one Plant - VP01

This plant is assigned to two sales areas VS01/10/00 and VS02/20/00 where 10 is for Direct Sales and 20 is for Export Sales.

Now when we are creating a return to the Export Vendor (BP extended to Sales area VS01/20/00 alone), we are getting the shipping point determination error because the system is searching for the shipping conditions in Sales area VS01/10/00 because in the ‚ÄúShipping data for plant‚Äù configuration, my plant has sales area VS01/10/00 maintained.

Now as this is an export vendor, we don‚Äôt extend it to sales areas VS01/10/00. Hence we are unable to perform the returns at all. 

So can anyone suggest how we can handle this case? Because we can‚Äôt keep changing the SPRO configuration Shipping data for plants again and again.

Should we implement any custom logic or can this be solved by standard SAP?

entry.title: Report:/SCMTMS/CHECK4ORPHANDODATA for orphan records in the database for dependent objects within TM
entry.content:
Report:/SCMTMS/CHECK4ORPHANDODATA for orphan records in the database for dependent objects within TM.

Overview

Following my previous blog for SAP TM Transaction WUF-Where-Used List - SAP Community  other part import after  Archiving  is consider the next steps of Orphaned data refers to records that exist in the database without corresponding references or relationships to other data, typically occurring when related records are deleted or modified in a way that breaks their connection to other data elements.

The /SCMTMS/CHECK4ORPHANDODATA report is a critical SAP Transportation Management (TM) utility designed to identify and clean up orphaned client-dependent data in the database.

This report is essential for maintaining data integrity during SAP S/4HANA conversions, upgrades, and system maintenance activities.

This report is particularly crucial during SAP S/4HANA conversion and upgrade processes

Report Parameters

 

Parameter

Description

Default Value

Notes

Client

Target client for orphan data check

Current client

Specify the client where orphan data should be identified

Test Mode

Execute in test mode without deletion

X (checked)

Recommended for initial analysis

Delete Mode

Actually, delete identified orphan data

(unchecked)

Use only after thorough testing

Object Types

Specific TM object types to check

All

Can be restricted to specific business objects

Execution Steps

  1. Navigate to Report
    • Transaction: SE38 or SE80
    • Program: /SCMTMS/CHECK4ORPHANDODATA
  2. Parameter Configuration
    • Set client parameter to target client
    • Enable test mode for initial run
    • Select specific object types if needed
    • Configure output options
  3. Execution Process
    • Execute the report in test mode first
    • Review the output for orphaned data candidates
    • Analyze the impact of potential deletions
    • Re-run in delete mode if appropriate
  4. Output Interpretation
    • Review list of orphaned objects identified
    • Check dependency relationships
    • Validate business impact before deletion

Common Issues and Solutions

Issue: Runtime Error DBSQL_STMNT_TOO_LARGE

Symptom:

  • Program terminates with runtime error DBSQL_STMNT_TOO_LARGE
  • Long execution time (many hours) before cancellation
  • Deletion of orphan data may not complete

Root Cause:

  • Large number of orphan records in database for dependent objects
  • SQL statement becomes too large for database processing

Resolution:

  1. Implement SAP Note 3701476 or relevant Support Package
  2. Consider processing data in smaller batches
  3. Review system resources and database configuration

Issue: Incomplete Orphan Data Detection

Symptom:

  • Report shows different numbers than expected
  • Inconsistent results compared to other TM reports

Root Cause:

  • Client deletion processes were interrupted or incomplete
  • Data inconsistencies at database level

Resolution:

  1. Check for abrupt/stopped client deletion status at SAP level
  2. Verify database-level orphaned client dependent data
  3. Run consistency checks before conversion activities

Output Analysis

  • Orphaned Objects: Review the list of business objects without valid parent references
  • Impact Assessment: Evaluate the business impact of removing identified orphaned data
  • Dependency Check: Ensure no active business processes depend on the identified data
  • Conversion Readiness: Confirm system readiness for S/4HANA conversion after cleanup

Related Transactions

  • SAAB: Checkpoint group activation for detailed logging
  • SE91: Message class analysis for error investigation
  • SE38: Report execution and debugging
  • SPRO: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide access

Best Practices

  • Pre-Conversion Execution: Always run this check before SAP S/4HANA conversion
  • Test Mode First: Execute in test mode before actual deletion
  • Backup Strategy: Ensure complete system backup before deletion activities
  • Scheduled Maintenance: Run during maintenance windows to avoid business disruption
  • Documentation: Document all findings and actions taken for audit purposes
  • Performance Monitoring: Monitor system performance during execution, especially for large datasets

 Refer to:

3701476 - Program /SCMTMS/CHECK4ORPHANDODATA with runtime error DBSQL_STMNT_TOO_LARGE - SAP for Me

3659947 - Check and cleanup orphan DO data - SAP for Me

3505013 - Delete step is not deleting data of dependent objects - SAP for Me

Hope this help you!

Thank you and regards.

Rogerio Lima.

entry.title: Re: Problems with the pricing condition on the SD invoice
entry.content:
Though you have indicated you have compared and same, still, check the following

  • Compare condition type ZPCI in both systems (V/06) for Condition category, origin, reference to valuation.
  • Compare pricing procedure assignment (V/08) and ensure ZPCI is set the same way in both.
  • Check copy control settings (VTFL/VTFA) for Pricing type which should allow redetermination.
  • Verify valuation integration and ensure PRD has the same valuation area settings as QA.
  • Run pricing analysis in billing document (transaction VF03 ‚Üí Environment ‚Üí Analysis) to see why ZPCI is being transferred instead of recalculated.

entry.title: Re: Plant in OBYC
entry.content: Direct plant assignment in OBYC is not possible. Indirect plant differentiation is possible if valuation level is set to plant. Otherwise, you need to use valuation classes or account modifiers to achieve plant‚Äëspecific G/L postings.

entry.title: Re: customer order exceeds credit limit and doesn't block...
entry.content: Yes ‚Äî negative receivables do impact the credit check in SAP. They reduce the exposure, which is why your large order did not block. If this is not the desired business behavior, you‚Äôll need to adjust credit management configuration or implement a BAdI to exclude negative receivables from the calculation. You can define which components are included in the static credit check. You can exclude credit memos or negative receivables from the exposure calculation.

entry.title: Maintenance operation status is changed back to "In Preparation" when assigning a user
entry.content:
Hi SAP Experts,

Can you please help me with the following behavior in SAP S/4HANA Public cloud, maintenance processes?

I have a maintenace order with type YA02 --> proactive maintenance order which is created via maintenance plan.
I release the order and then  I use the app "Perform Maintenace Jobs" and assign the operation to my user. Then, the operation is removed from the list.
I've found out that this happens, because the staus of the operation is changed back to "In Preparation" and the operation is not DSPT anymore. For YA01 orders, it works perfectly: The operation stays in the list and I can start working (create a confirmation)

Steps to Reproduce 

  1. Open Maintenance Order (YA02)
  2. Release the order
  3. Additonal Functions: Dispatch Operations
  4. Save and "read only"
    --> Status of all operations: REL DSPT and Subphase = Ready for Execution
  5. Open App "Perform Maintenance Jobs" and search for the order
  6. Select the first operation
  7. Click on "Assign to me" 
    --> operation is not visible in the app anymore
  8. Open Maintenance Order
    --> Status of first operation: REL and Subphase = In Preparation

BR
Simon

entry.title: Call for Speakers ‚Äì SAP Inside Track NRW
entry.content:
Call for Speakers ‚Äì SAP Inside Track NRW

After several years without a regional SAP Inside Track in our area, it‚Äôs time to bring the community back together. Therefore We are excited to announce SAP Inside Track NRW 2026 ‚Äî and we‚Äôre now opening the Call for Speakers. Some of you may remember the legendary sitPOTT from 7 years ago. Those events showed how strong, curious, and hands‚Äëon the SAP community in NRW can be. We want to build on that spirit: informal, practical, and full of real project experience.

 

What we‚Äôre looking for

We welcome contributions from across the SAP universe, including but not limited to:

  • SAP BTP, CAP, UI5, ABAP, Integration Suite
  • Analytics, Data & AI, Security, Cloud Operations
  • Project insights, architecture decisions, lessons learned
  • Demos, prototypes, experiments, or ‚Äúthis is what we tried and how it went‚Äù stories

Whether you have spoken at many events or this would be your first time on stage if you have something worth sharing, we‚Äôd love to hear from you.

 

Session format

  • Duration: 30‚Äì40 minutes or 15-20 Minutes.
  • Format: Presentation, live demo, interactive session ‚Äî whatever fits your topic
  • Language: English

 

Event details

  • Event: SAP Inside Track NRW
  • Date: 13. Juni 2026
  • Location: On-Site Adesso Dortmund

 

How to submit your session

Please utilize the following Microsoft Form to submit a Topic Call for Speakers: SAP Inside Track NRW.

entry.title: SAP Inside Track NRW
entry.content:
We‚Äôre bringing a regional SAP Inside Track back to NRW, and we‚Äôd love to see you there. After the memorable sitPOTT from soon to be 7 years ago, it‚Äôs time to revive that spirit of learning, networking, and hands on exchange. SAP Inside Track NRW will be a day shaped by the community: practical sessions, real project insights, and plenty of opportunities to connect with people who work with SAP technologies every day.

 

What to expect

  • A full day of sessions from community speakers
  • Topics across SAP BTP, ABAP, UI5, Integration, Analytics, Security, and more
  • Space for discussions, questions, and sharing your own experiences
  • A relaxed atmosphere ‚Äî no suits required
  • Networking with familiar faces and new ones

 

Event details

  • Event: SAP Inside Track NRW
  • Date: June 13, 2026
  • Location: On-Site Adesso Dortmund
  • Registration: Will be opened soon
  • Admission: free

 

Who should join

Whether you‚Äôre deep into SAP or just curious about what‚Äôs happening in the ecosystem, you‚Äôre welcome:

  • Developers
  • Architects
  • Consultants
  • Students
  • Tech enthusiasts
  • Community veterans (including those who still remember sitPott)

 

Why attend

SAP Inside Tracks are built by the community, for the community. They‚Äôre not polished marketing events. They‚Äôre places where people speak openly about what works, what doesn‚Äôt, and what they‚Äôve learned along the way. If you enjoy practical insights more than glossy slides, you‚Äôll feel right at home.

Here‚Äôs what makes attending worthwhile:

  • Practical experience instead of theory Speakers talk about what they‚Äôve actually built, broken, fixed, or learned along the way. No slideware, no buzzwords - just real insights you can take back to work the very next day.
  • Learning beyond your own SAP bubble Whether your focus is BTP, ABAP, UI5, Integration, Analytics, or Security, the sessions are designed to widen your view and connect the dots between disciplines.
  • Open exchange with experts and peers Ask questions, challenge ideas, and get honest answers from people who deal with the same problems you do.
  • A relaxed and welcoming setting Inside Tracks are deliberately informal. No suits, no stage personas, no pressure just people who enjoy sharing knowledge and learning from each other.
  • Networking that happens naturally Conversations start over coffee, during breaks, or while someone shows a quick demo on their laptop. Many long standing community connections began exactly like this including at the old sitPOTT
  • Fresh ideas for your own projects Seeing how others approach challenges often sparks new ways of thinking. Many attendees leave with ideas they hadn‚Äôt even considered before.
  • Reconnecting the NRW SAP community It‚Äôs been a long time since the last event in NRW. This event is about bringing that spirit back and giving the regional SAP community a place to meet, exchange, and grow again.

entry.title: Integration Suite API Management CF custom domain activation via self-service
entry.content:
Introduction

In this blog post you will learn how to setup and activate custom domains (standard setup not mTLS) for SAP Integration Suite API management runtime based on Cloud Foundry via de self-service procedure. If you already have a custom domain activate and in the past this was performed by SAP, this is the blog for you. 

To keep this blog to the point the focus is to provide detailed steps and information for this case. Information about obtaining a certificate, create a virtual host for API Management or updating DNS records are only briefly touched.

Prerequisites

To follow the steps explained please make sure you have or gathered:

  • Administrator access to the subaccount in which Integration Suite is running. To be able to:
    • Provide required authorizations
    • Create/Update service keys
  • SAP Integration Suite, API management is setup and running. Launchpad is accessible.
  • SAP API management a test API is published and working with the standard SAP domain.
  • DNS administrator authorization or a contact within the organization authorized to perform the required activity.
  • Certificate administrator authorization or a contact within the organization authorized to perform the required activity.
  • A HTTP Client like Postman for executing API calls.
    • Access to api.sap.com for details on the required API actions

API Management Service key

Before we are able to call any APIs for information and activities with API management it is important a service key is created with specific authorizations: APIManagement.SelfService.Administrator using the plan apiportal-apiaccess. To create an instance you need to navigate towards: Home page Global account->subaccount for integration suite->left hand menu Services->Instances and subscriptions->create instance with the following details, using the correct Space:

As a result the output should look like below:

This service key is required for all upcoming activities to validate existing virtual hosts and create/update a virtual host for custom domain usage.

APIM virtual host overview

Assumption is the service key is created and active. As a first step try to retrieve a token for the service key, my examples are from Postman:

As noticed you can here also validate when the response is positive the authorization is properly linked.

After this step is completed you can call the endpoint:

  • {hostname from servicekey URL}/apiportal/operations/1.0/Configuration.svc/VirtualHostRequests

with the hostname from the service key, with the HTTP GET method this should result in the overview of virtual hosts for the API Management instance. If you currently only have the SAP standard domain this is the only record to be returned.

APIM create virtual host (optional)

This step is optional and only required if not additional virtual host is already created

A virtual host for APIM can easily be created calling the endpoint: 

  • {hostname from servicekey URL}/apiportal/operations/1.0/Configuration.svc/VirtualHostRequests including the body as:
{
    "accountId": "{accountId}",
    "virtualHostUrl": "{desired virtual host prefix}",
    "isDefaultVirtualHostRequest": false,
    "operation": "CREATE"
}
To be sure the virtual host is created it should result in a positive response and it should become visible in APIM within the API proxy section, as example below:

APIM read virtual hosts - available

Retrieving all virtual hosts for an APIM instance is handled via the same URL mentioned a couple of times in this blog: 

  • {hostname from servicekey URL}/apiportal/operations/1.0/Configuration.svc/VirtualHostRequests 

a response looks like:

Important fields are highlighted which are required to create/update a custom domain for the created virtual host.

APIM create keystore for custom domain

Compared to SAP Cloud Integration custom domain which is handled via de Custom Domain Manager UI for APIM this is not working in the same concept. This also means the required certificate needs to be created differently and more information is required. For APIM a certificate needs to be bought/requested from the used CA within the company without using an CSR from SAP.  In this blog we are using a wildcard certificate which is used for all APIM environments.

The certificate details you need to create a keystore are:

  • private key 
  • public key
  • certificate chain including root and intermediate certificates

Important is that the certificate needs to be in a .pem format. In our case we already get the certificates delivered in .pem format. It is important the the public key part including the certificate chain is created in the following order in which the first entry is at the top: 

  1. public key client certificate
  2. intermediate certificates (if any is available)
  3. root CA

And saved as a .pem file. The exact steps to create the keystore including the required content is described in SAP documentation: https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/manage-certificates . To create a JAR file we used the JAVA JDK as a download (not required to install) in combination with PowerShell:

In PowerShell the following commmands are used:

  • Create JAR keystore: {location java JDK}\bin\jar -cf customdomain.jar main.pem privateKey.pem
  • Update JAR keystore with META-INF information: {location java JDK}\bin\jar -uf customdomain.jar META-INF/descriptor.properties

When the creation is successful this keystore needs to be uploaded.

APIM upload keystore for custom domain

The upload step is very simple. Navigate within SAP Integration Suite overview page towards: Left hand menu Configure->APIs->Tab: Certificates :

and click the create button with the following setup:

Important is to select Key Store and New Store. The Store Name and Name value can be anything you like within the boundaries of what SAP allows and in the upload field you need to select the created JAR file. If you select update it will give a warning the create is the approach. In case you select update and you upload a new certificate the already existing one is overwritten with the same name.

If the upload is going as expected it will be listed in the tab Certificates.

APIM activate custom domain

If all previous steps are completed successfully, activation can start. Be aware of the following:

  • The used root CA for custom domain needs to be trusted by applications/systems to be able to make a working connection.
  • Make a decision if the custom domain needs to be the default domain when creating or importing an API proxy. We decided not to use the custom domain as default virtual host.
  • After custom domain activation you need to
    • update any existing DNS CNAME records. The target URL will change. However this URL will only be available after the activation is executed via an API call. This target value can be located in field lbHost in the response from the activation when this is positive.
    • redeploy all API proxies using the custom domain and as a second step all API products. This to make sure the correct certificate is used. This is especially important when the custom domain is already used and the certificate chain is changed.

Activation for custom domain is handled via an API call:

  • {hostname from servicekey URL}/apiportal/operations/1.0/Configuration.svc/VirtualHostRequests

With the following content:

{
    "accountId" : "{accountId from read operation}",  
    "virtualHostUrl": "{full custom domain with virtual host prefix}",
    "isDefaultVirtualHostRequest" : false,
    "isForCustomDomain": true,
    "keyStoreName": "{created during keystore upload}",
    "keyStoreAlias": "{created during keystore upload}",
    "operation" : "UPDATE",
    "virtualHostId":"{virtualHostId from read operation}"
}
A positive response should look like:

The values in fields virtualHostUrl and lbHost are important for updating the CNAME record in DNS. 

APIM create/update custom domain DNS CNAME

To make sure the custom domain can be reached and is forwarded to the correct endpoint a DNS CNAME record is required for every APIM virtual host activated for custom domain. In our case we already had a CNAME record for our custom domain pointing to the standard SAP domain [

test.apimanagement.eu20.hana.ondemand.com] as provided by SAP when they initially handled the custom domain activities for APIM.  As mentioned in the previous paragraph the CNAME now needs to be:
  • virtualHostUrl value -> lbHost value

Be aware in case you use multiple virtual host in an APIM environment the lbHost value might be the same but this is not causing any issues related to call the correct endpoints.

After it is validated via DNS checkers the CNAME record is updated the first step is to activate 1 API proxy and the linked API product and validate the correct routing and certificates are handled. We decided to edit the API proxy and perform a dummy change and updated the revision with details about the redeployment. Other options are also available.

In our case we used temporary a testing endpoint specific for the custom domain validation. We also provided this endpoint to application, system and partner contacts for validation purposes and to request them to validate if the root CA is available in the trust store.

Conclusion

The switch from SAP managed custom domains for our organization towards self-service is a logical one. We got confronted with the self-service approach 5 working days prior to the current certificate expiring which gave us clear time contraints. Luckily the creation of the virtual host and retrieval of the overview of virtual hosts was already known for us and the service key already existed.

Looking at the SAP documentation most steps are stated (high-level) in multiple pages however from our perspective some pieces of documentation raised questions from our end. With a ticket towards SAP we received definitive clarification to get this change done correctly without any disruptions. This is the reason the blog was written.

Hopefully this blog is giving others the insights and information required to make this working properly within the own organization.

Documentation & Links

If you like to read more information about custom domains and the setup it requires for other cases I can recommend reading the below helpful information:

  • Request or update an APIM custom domain: https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-api-management/sap-api-management/requesting-for-custom-domain-for-virtual-host 
  • Create a JAR keystore: https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/manage-certificates
  • Configure DNS for a custom domain: https://help.sap.com/docs/custom-domain/custom-domain-service/configure-dns-for-custom-domain

entry.title: Re: Why would SAP not turn Recyclebin on to help in recov...
entry.content:
Hi,

the recycle bin is turned off since Oracle 10g because it was causing a lot of issues especially using BW.  The decision has been made after throughout analysis and the collected experiences.

Instead of using the recycle bin, we support the usage of flashback database, flashback table. Although not the same, but still can be used in case of some user made mistakes.

entry.title: Re: Issue with shipping point during Return To Vendor
entry.content:
Why the error occurs is because, in SPRO ‚Üí Enterprise Structure ‚Üí Assignment ‚Üí Logistics Execution ‚Üí Shipping ‚Üí Assign shipping data to plant, you can only assign one sales area per plant. When you create a return order, the system looks at Plant (from item), Shipping conditions (from sales area/customer master) & Loading group (from material master). Since the plant VP01 is tied to sales area VS01/10/00 in customizing, the system tries to fetch shipping conditions from that sales area, even though your BP is only extended to VS01/20/00 and the result is shipping point determination fails.

You don‚Äôt need custom logic; there are standard ways to handle this:

Assign Plant to Multiple Sales Areas via Common Distribution Channel/Division
SAP allows you to define common distribution channels and divisions. If you set up VS01/10/00 and VS01/20/00 to share a common distribution channel/division, the plant assignment can be reused across both. This way, shipping point determination works for both sales areas without changing SPRO each time.

Use Customer Master Shipping Conditions
Maintain the correct shipping condition in the export customer master (BP ‚Üí Sales Area ‚Üí Shipping tab). The system will then use that shipping condition in combination with plant + loading group to determine the shipping point, even if the plant is linked to another sales area.

entry.title: Re: In MTO, Sequent ion of Material Production is not wel...
entry.content:
Your FG has multiple possible production paths depending on raw material quality. Standard BOM explosion in MRP will create planned orders for all SFG levels defined in the BOM. In reality, only certain operations (e.g. Grinding + Packing, or Annealing + Grinding + Packing) are required. The challenge is: how to tell the system to skip unnecessary planned orders and consume raw material directly at the correct stage.

Standard SAP Approaches

1. Alternative BOMs
Maintain multiple BOMs for the FG. BOM 1 ‚Üí Grinding + Packing and BOM 2 ‚Üí Annealing + Grinding + Packing. At order creation, select the correct BOM based on raw material quality. MRP will then only generate planned orders for the chosen path.

Advantage: clean separation of production paths.
Limitation: requires manual or rule‚Äëbased BOM selection.

2. Production Versions
Link each BOM + Routing combination to a Production Version. Example PV1 ‚Üí BOM with Grinding + Packing. PV2 ‚Üí BOM with Annealing + Grinding + Packing. MRP uses the production version to determine which operations/components are relevant. You can control which production version is valid by lot size, validity dates, or business rules.

Advantage: standard, flexible, widely used in MTO scenarios.

3. Phantom Assemblies (Special Procurement Key 50)
Model intermediate SFGs (Drawing, Annealing, Grinding) as phantom assemblies. Phantom assemblies explode in the BOM but do not generate separate planned orders. Raw material consumption can then be directly pegged to the FG or the required operation.

Advantage: avoids unnecessary planned orders.
Limitation: use only if SFG stock is not managed separately.

4. Engineering Workbench / Variant Configuration (Advanced)
If the choice of path depends on raw material characteristics, you can use variant configuration or classification to select the right BOM/routing dynamically. This is more advanced but allows the system to ‚Äúdecide‚Äù automatically which operations are required.

Having said that, the recommended approach would be

  • Use Production Versions with alternative BOMs/routings.
  • Model optional SFGs as phantom assemblies if you don‚Äôt want separate orders.
  • At order creation, select the correct production version based on raw material quality.
  • This ensures MRP generates only the required planned orders and consumption is posted correctly.

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud Certification (C_BCBDC): The Ultimate Guide to Passing SAP‚Äôs New AI Scenario
entry.content:
Introduction

Certification is changing, and it is a good thing. Instead of cramming facts and guessing at multiple choice, you are invited to think like you do on the job. You will work through real scenarios, connect the dots, and show how you deliver outcomes. In this post we will talk about what is new, and how to prepare for SAP BDC (C_BCBDC) certification.

Understanding the New BDC Certification Format - Scenario Based

You will interact with an AI avatar to respond to real customer or project situations. For learners who prefer not to use AI there is an alternative option to upload a video for human review. Link for more details : SAP Certification is Changing What You Need to Know about the New Format, Reimagining Certification

Preparation

SAP BDC Learning Journey

For the best chance of success, complete the full SAP Business Data Cloud learning journey from start to finish. Treat every module, hands on exercise, and quiz as required to build real exam readiness. Give special attention to the core topics below

Core Topics in SAP Business Data Cloud

1. BDC

  • One domain model
  • SAP 4 Me
  • Formations
  • Intelligent Applications
  • Data Products
  • Data Security
  • Architecture
  • BDC Cockpit
  • Zero copy
  • ORD / CSN
  • Data Lake

2. SAP Datasphere Integration

  • BDC-generated spaces
  • Harmonization through modeling
  • Semantic enrichment
  • Extending SAP-delivered models
  • Installing data products to a space

3. SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

  • Role of SAC in BDC
  • Extending and discovering intelligent applications
  • Use cases for intelligent applications

4. BW Modernization

  • Lift, shift, and innovate strategies
  • Data Product Generator
  • Subscriptions and versions
  • Why BW is included in BDC

5. SAP Databricks Integration

  • ML Flow, delta share, notebooks, Unity Catalog
  • Exploratory Data Analysis
  • Industry use cases
  • Sharing data products and ML results between Databricks and BDC

Sample Scenarios to Understand the Exam Format

Scenario 1: Global Manufacturing Company ‚Äì Unified Analytics & Governance

Context: A global manufacturing company operates across Europe and Asia. They run SAP S/4HANA, legacy SAP BW, and several non-SAP systems for logistics and procurement. Leadership wants a single, governed analytics platform with reusable data products and ready-made insights.

Question: How does BDC help

Scenario 2: Financial Services Firm ‚Äì AI-Driven Risk & Compliance Reporting

Context: A financial services firm needs real-time risk reporting, strict compliance, and AI-driven forecasting. They must integrate SAP finance data with external market feeds and apply advanced analytics.

Question: How can Financial Services Firm integrate third-party data with its SAP data using SAP Business Data Cloud?

Exam Questions Breakdown from My Attempt

Based on my recent experience, here‚Äôs how the exam questions were distributed:

  • Technical Knowledge of BDC: 40%
  • Integration with SAP Business Warehouse: 15%
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Analytics Cloud: 15%
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Datasphere: 15%
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Databricks: 15%

Helpful Links

  1. Exploring SAP Business Data Cloud Learning Journey
  2. SAP Certification is Changing What You Need to Know about the New Format
  3. Reimagining Certification
  4. SAP Certified Associate SAP Business Data Cloud

entry.title: Re: Returns to Vendor process using Advanced Returns Mana...
entry.content:
Hi @AAkash1 ,

In SAP S/4HANA Advanced Returns Management, you create a Return Purchase Order directly with reference to the original PO using the returns functionality (not a standard ME21N transaction). The system links the new Return PO to the original PO, so yes‚Äîyou can track the original purchase order from the newly created return document.

Steps in Vendor Returns with Advanced Returns Management
Purchase Order creation ‚Üí Standard PO created in ME21N.
Inbound delivery ‚Üí Goods receipt posted against the PO.
Inspection/decision ‚Üí If goods are defective or need to be returned, initiate Advanced Returns Management.

Use Advanced Returns Management to create the Return PO with reference to the original PO. The system automatically links them, so you can track the original purchase order from the return document. ME21N alone won‚Äôt give you the full integration benefits.

entry.title: Re: Storing of documents in database table

entry.title: Re: Issue with SAP BAS Project Creation: "No Database Ava...
entry.content: In SAP BTP trial accounts, this error usually occurs when the SAP HANA Cloud instance is not fully provisioned, not running, or not available in the same space where the BAS project is being created. Please ensure that the HANA Cloud instance is created and active in the dev space, and that it is visible for HDI container creation during project setup. If the problem persists in a trial environment, it is often caused by trial resource limitations or delayed service availability, in which case re-creating the instance or using a different space typically resolves the issue.

entry.title: Re: Minimum grants required for m_expensive_statement_trace
entry.content: In SAP HANA, access to SYS.M_EXPENSIVE_STATEMENTS requires monitoring privileges and cannot be granted in full isolation. Restricting a user to only HANA Studio/SQL Console while blocking Cockpit or other clients is not supported via HANA authorization; such restrictions must be enforced outside the database (e.g. network or tool level).

entry.title: Re: How to add User Provided Service using HDI Container...
entry.content: Yes. User-provided services are handled at the MTA/Cloud Foundry level, not via the HDI Container API. You create the UPS in the space, reference it in mta.yaml as an org.cloudfoundry.existing-service, bind it to the DB deployer, and then use .hdbgrants and synonyms to access objects from the external schema.

entry.title: Re: Can we connect Actual On Premise DataBase to Cloud AL...
entry.content: SAP Cloud ALM does not support direct monitoring of standalone on-premise databases. For on-premise landscapes, database monitoring in Cloud ALM is available only in the context of a connected ABAP system and is limited to the health and metrics exposed by that system. Advanced database-level monitoring, such as detailed backup status or DB-internal checks, must continue to be handled with on-premise tools (for example SAP Solution Manager or native database monitoring).

Through SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council (ESAC), we collaborate directly with customers like you to continuously enhance essential services and support content across all cloud solutions.

ESAC is a collaborative innovation program that brings together SAP experts and a select group of customers to explore new ideas, share feedback, and help shape the future of SAP Enterprise Support.

By participating in ESAC, you can:

entry.title: Re: SAP Hana error: Unable to find service undefined while trying to create a hdb calculaton view in
entry.content:
This usually happens when BAS can‚Äôt resolve the HANA service binding for your project, so the data-source picker ends up calling a ‚Äúservice = undefined‚Äù.

Please check that your project actually has an HDI container service bound and deployed: the mta.yaml must include an HDI container resource, your db module must require it, and the MTA needs to be deployed so the HDI container instance exists in the same org/space. After that, re-open the dev space (or restart the dev space) and reload the Calculation View editor so it picks up the bound service.

entry.title: Re: Partially ordered PRs in Ariba

entry.title: Re: SAP PUBLIC CLOUD By cloud connector and BTP Destination call (internal network) API
entry.content:
Hi James,

Please check te documentation here: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/4320255b3e0b4892bf13cebe7583a3d3.html?version=2508.500 

All host names, instance numbers, and ports that you use in communication systems that use Cloud Connector are virtual names that you configure in your Cloud Connector. So you could map the internal IP address/port to a virtual host name/port that you can then reference in you communication system.

Regards,
Peter

entry.title: Key User Custom Fields: Finding the business context for a given database table
entry.content:
Key User Custom Fields: Finding the business context for a given database table  

Have you ever been in a situation where you wanted to add a key user custom field to a given database table (e.g. ACDOCA or VBAK), but you did not know which business context to choose? 

Or are you right in the middle of an ECC to SAP S/4HANA migration project, and you have legacy custom fields in your ECC system? You want to recreate custom fields in SAP S/4HANA, and you don‚Äôt know which business context to choose?  

If your answer is yes, then this blog post is just for you. In this blog, you‚Äôll find out how to determine the right business context based on a given database table name (or CI-include name or extension include name). 
The ways to determine the right business context differ between SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (and on premise).

How do business contexts relate to database tables?  

When you create a custom field using the Custom Fields app, you must first choose a business context. A business context describes the business entity which you want to extend. Technically, each business context has an include structure assigned, which is directly or transitively included in one or more database tables. This include structure is also called persistence include or extension include structure. 
If you add a custom field to a business context, this field is added to the respective persistence include structure using an append structure. With that, all database tables and structures which include this persistence include structure automatically also get this field. 

You can get more detailed information in the following SAP Help documentation: Handling_of_Legacy_Fields.pdf 
 
Now that you have an idea of how business contexts relate to database tables, let‚Äôs understand  

  1. how to figure out the respective business context for a given database table and 
  1. how to figure out the database table(s) which get extended when you add a field to a business context 

Figuring out the business context based on a given object in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and on premise 

Report CFD_GET_BUS_CTXTS_BY_DB_TABLE allows you to enter a database table name, a CI-include name, or an extension include name. When running the report, all business contexts that expose fields in the respective database table/CI-include/extension include are listed. 
This report is part of SAP note 3699976 - Custom Fields: find business contexts for db table

Figuring out database table(s) that are extended by a business context in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and on premise 

Report CFD_GET_DB_TABLES_BY_BUS_CTXT allows you to enter a business context name. As a result, a list of all database tables that contain the fields of the given business context is displayed. This report is also part of SAP note 3699976 - Custom Fields: find business contexts for db table 

Figuring out the business context based on a given database table in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you can use the Extensibility Assistant (see this blog for details) that helps you to create and maintain custom fields. In one of the next releases (probably already with the 2608 release) the Extensibility Assistant will also be able to tell you which business context to choose to extend a given database table. If you enter a prompt like ‚ÄúWhich business context should I use in order to extend table VBAK?‚Äù, the extensibility assistant will be able to help you. 

Please note that this blog has been elaborated by a team of experts. I want to thank‚ÄØYasmina van Rooij‚ÄØ(YasminavanRooij),‚ÄØ and Karsten Schaser (Karsten_Schaser) for their extremely helpful contributions. 

Feedback, Comments, or Questions: 

You‚Äôre cordially invited to provide feedback, comments, or questions in the comments section below. Please follow our profiles to get updates when we publish more posts on these topics. 
Feel invited to post and answer questions here (https://answers.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26) and read other posts on the topic (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26/). 

Other related blog posts: 

  1. Extensibility Assistant for Key Users: The extensibility expert right next to you  
  1. Key User Custom Fields in S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and On-Premise: Dos and Don‚Äôts  
  1. Convert Manually Created Append Fields to Real Key User Custom Fields

entry.title: Re: SAP MDG: Validation - No Special Characters in Account Holder Field
entry.content:
Hi @sandeep_suggu ,

Thank you for this blog.

Also, I would like to add an alternative approach for checking special characters. Please see the example below:

PARAMETERS p_text TYPE string DEFAULT 'abc*'.

IF matches(
     val  = p_text
     pcre = '^[A-Za-z0-9]*$'
   ).
  WRITE / |No special character found: { p_text }|.
ELSE.
  WRITE / |Special character found: { p_text }|.
ENDIF.

With this approach, there is no need to explicitly handle special characters. The validation ensures that the string contains only alphanumeric characters (letters and digits).

entry.title: Re: how can we manually maintain SOD in S4 hana without G...
entry.content: As I know, in S/4HANA, segregation of duties cannot be systematically maintained or enforced without SAP GRC or a third-party tool; without these, SoD can only be handled manually via role design and periodic authorization reviews.

entry.content:
That's too bad. Either that means VARIANT_INIT_F14 isn't called when you submit the report, or a different value is assigned to variable g_variant_save before DISPLAY_LIST_F14 is called.

Debug to find out. I don't have any other tips.

entry.title: Re: TMG typing new entries instead of search help question
entry.content:
As I said, I don't recommend your solution, but if you really want to continue with it, use DYNP_UPDATE_FIELDS with the screen line number in the component STEPL of the parameter DYNPFIELDS (top line of the screen = always 1).

From the F4 logic, use F4UT_GET_ENVIRONMENT to retrieve the line number (component STEPLNUM) where F4 is pressed.

entry.title: Event mesh design
entry.content:
Hi,
We are designing system to asynchronously handle traffic form multiple data centers where each data center can have several hostnames/servers. We currently have one API application that would consume the data from all of the data centers. Now, the first option is to design the queue for each data center and subscribe corresponding topic to each queue. So, if we have for example three data centers (in reality tens of them) HEC45, HEC44, HEC55 then we would have for example queue with this name Queue_HEC45 and topic name hec45 and so on. In this case the application would be subscribed and received on push notification the data from all of the data centers. 

What would be recommended approach to design such system? 
What do you think in terms of pursuing SAP Advanced Event Mesh (Solace) instead of SAP Event Mesh? 
We definitely need guaranteed delivery, dynamic message routing in case of more consumer applications.

Thanks!
